plants.name: Helianthus annuus
plants.description: Large annual plant known for its tall stems and bright, yellow flower heads that track the sun throughout the day. Native to North America, widely cultivated and naturalized globally.
plants.bloomingSeason: Mid-summer to early fall (July to September)
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, originally North America
plants.funFact: Sunflowers can grow up to 3 meters tall and their seeds are harvested for both food and oil.

plants.name: Rhododendron
plants.description: Shrubs or small trees that produce large clusters of bell-shaped flowers. Many species bloom in spring, but some, especially in cooler climates, bloom late summer.
plants.location: Temperate regions, particularly mountainous areas in Asia, Europe, and North America
plants.funFact: Rhododendrons contain compounds that can be toxic if ingested, yet they're treasured for their ornamental beauty.

plants.name: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis
plants.description: Tropical shrub with large, showy flowers typically blooming throughout warm months. Favored in tropical and subtropical gardens worldwide.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round in tropical climates; peak bloom in summer (June to August)
plants.funFact: Hibiscus flowers usually last only a day, but they bloom continuously to create a long flowering season.

plants.name: Lupinus perennis
plants.description: Perennial wildflower with tall spikes covered in pea-like flowers, important for native pollinators and habitat restoration.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to mid-summer; in some northern regions, bloom can extend into early August
plants.location: Eastern North America, especially sandy soils and prairies
plants.funFact: Wild Lupine is the exclusive host plant for the endangered Karner blue butterfly.
